messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] buddhist Wheel
messages.msgSnippet: Rich et al- Looks more like a wagon wheel to me or perhaps a waterwheel. Isn t this the wheel in waves design? It lacks the points found on a rimbo... -t
messages.messageBody:
Rich et al-
Looks more like a wagon wheel to me or perhaps a waterwheel. Isn't
this the wheel in waves design? It lacks the "points" found on a
rimbo...
-t

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] buddhist Wheel
messages.msgSnippet: Interesting tsuba, Rich. I like the use of chidori and pine bark designs. Ron STL ... From: Richard Turner To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com Sent: Monday,
messages.messageBody:
Interesting tsuba, Rich. I like the use of "chidori" and "pine bark" designs.

Ron
STL

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] buddhist Wheel
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, I read the points as matsukawabishi rather then ken or vajra (kongosho).  The rinpo (Buddhist wheels) that I can recall seeing are 8 pointed, although
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
I read the points as matsukawabishi rather then ken or vajra (kongosho). The rinpo (Buddhist wheels) that I can recall seeing are 8 pointed, although this page on mon shows 3 and 5 point versions.

http://www.harimaya.com/o_kamon1/yurai/a_yurai/pack2/rinpo.html

The birds around the rim of the tsuba would also be unusual if it represents a rinpo. I've seen variations of this design also, but I don't know what the four 10-spoked wheels represent. I haven't done any digging on it.
Jim



all, is this a buddhist wheel them, I have seen this ( I think ) with the 4 wheels and 4 ken before were as these seem to be 4 wheels and circling Mon.

http://img36.ac.yahoo.co.jp/users/5/6/3/7/kurara_5510-img595x600-1073713428p1040875.jpg
